column4: it kinda makes sense - write speeds are generally much much lower than read speeds - especially from USB devices -- also, reading from /dev/{zero,null} is much faster than /dev/urandom  by virtue of how /dev/urandom works
yes but why is it faster for me to write from /dev/urandom then /dev/zero
what's unusual tho is the 500K/s write speeds you get
the /dev/urandom 2.7 MB/s is the bottleneck of /dev/urandom
you said - /dev/zero gives you ~27 MB/s - that's faster than urandom
i don't get it - what are you asking really? :)
zero -> sdb is 500 KB/s. zero -> null is 27.8 MB/s. urandom -> sdb is 2.8 MB/s, urandom -> null is 2.8 MB/s
For some reason zero -> sdb is REALLY slow
have you played with the blocksizes?
try increasing the blocksizes --   dd ... bd=16384
that seems to work unop, which is weird I did this three weeks ago without bs, and it's fine
Now I'm getting 9.04 MB/s, except it's dropping really fast
might be drive caching at play there
